outcomes.description: The project facilitated the formation and strengthening of equitable partnerships and networks across multiple stakeholder groups in the livestock vaccine landscape through stakeholder consultations conducted in Senegal, Ethiopia, Kenya, and Bangladesh. The project enabled the identification of and relationship-building with key partners from the private sector, governments, and civil society, bringing together public sector research organizations, pharmaceutical and biotech companies, regulators, non-governmental organizations, and representatives of livestock holders. These consultations established new contacts with various stakeholders and enabled deeper understanding of the needs of smallholder farmers regarding vaccines, including their concerns about low-quality vaccines from state-led laboratories. The partnerships formed positioned the Livestock Vaccine Innovation Fund (LVIF) to maximize the impact of newly identified and existing vaccine candidates through multi-actor collaboration.

outcomes.description: The Animal Health program strengthened its institutional capacity to integrate gender equality and inclusion into its programming by dedicating additional resources to this critical area following challenges encountered in developing an initial gender report. In 2019, the LVIF program funded a cohort of four projects specifically designed to empower women as entrepreneurs, livestock farmers, and service providers in the livestock vaccines distribution and delivery chain. These projects adopted a novel approach by being led by gender experts rather than adding gender experts to teams of animal health/vaccine experts, which reduced the risk of gender issues becoming sidelined and ensured higher-quality gender results. project_name: Development and deployment of a subunit   vaccine against bovine babesiosis - Phase 2

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested a dual-acting subunit vaccine against bovine babesiosis, a tick-borne disease affecting livestock production systems. The research team identified, produced, and characterized multiple recombinant protein vaccine candidates including blood-stage antigens (BbSA1, BbSA3, BbSA4, BbMAP1, and 11C5) and tick-stage antigens (HAP2), with the goal of both preventing acute disease and blocking parasite transmission between tick vectors and cattle hosts. Vaccination trials with the HAP2 sexual-stage protein demonstrated the ability to abrogate parasite transmission by Rhipicephalus microplus ticks, representing a significant advancement in transmission-blocking vaccine technology. Although final testing of the dual-acting vaccine encountered challenges that prevented proof of concept completion, the project generated substantial technical knowledge disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations that can guide future vaccine development. The innovations included advancement of methodological capacity, new vaccine technologies, and improved delivery systems for this neglected livestock disease.

outcomes.description: The Livestock Vaccine Innovation Fund (LVIF) was established as a major multi-funder partnership bringing together the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF), Global Affairs Canada (GAC), and IDRC in a 57 million CAD, 8-year collaboration. This equitable partnership adopted a strategic model intervening at key entry points in the vaccine development, production, and access continuum, carrying out research activities along three streams: cutting-edge vaccine development, vaccine improvement and manufacturing, and vaccine demand, access, and use. The Fund supported eight projects through the initial discovery phase covering novel vaccine development for a range of livestock diseases (including African Swine Fever, Avian Flu, Foot and Mouth Disease, and bovine babesiosis), with several promising projects subsequently given Phase 2 funding to advance vaccines towards industry proof of concept. Grantees at this phase were primarily research institutes and universities, representing a multi-actor coalition formed to deliver livestock vaccine innovations supporting climate-resilient food systems.

outcomes.description: The project generated substantial high-quality research and evidence on vaccine development for bovine babesiosis, a tick-borne disease affecting livestock in tropical and subtropical regions. The research team produced and tested multiple blood-stage antigens (BbSA1, BbSA3, BbSA4, BbMAP1, 11C5) and tick-stage antigens (HAP2) as vaccine candidates, redefined genomic regions, and validated antigenicity, purity, and identity of vaccine antigens. This knowledge was disseminated through four peer-reviewed papers and two invited reviews in international journals (including CABI Reviews, Nature Vaccines, and Frontiers series), six presentations at major international scientific conferences (including International Babesiosis meetings, WAAVP, and parasitology conferences), and one patent filing for a transmission-blocking vaccine. Although the final dual-acting vaccine trial was inconclusive, the project produced significant technical knowledge on livestock disease control strategies applicable to other tick-borne diseases, contributing to climate-resilient food systems and advancing the vaccine development field after three decades of research community efforts.

project_name: Use of CRISPR/cas9 gene editing for   increased vaccine yields in avian cell lines - Phase 2

outcomes.description: The project successfully developed and tested CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing technology to improve cell-based vaccine production for poultry diseases such as avian influenza and Newcastle disease. Phase 2 testing under industrial conditions with vaccine producers in Vietnam, Egypt, and South Africa demonstrated significantly higher viral yields in edited cells compared to non-edited cells and embryonated chicken eggs. The innovation was transferred to vaccine manufacturers in LMICs including Deltamune (South Africa), Fivevet Central Veterinary Medicine JSC (Vietnam), and Vaccine Valley (Egypt), providing a more sustainable and faster vaccine production method. The project advanced methodological capacity, new vaccine technologies, and improved delivery systems that have the potential to be of extreme economic importance for poultry vaccine manufacturers and smallholder livestock farmers in regions where poultry diseases are endemic.

filename: 109618 PCR - A non-replicative adenovirus vaccine platform for poultry diseases - Phase 2.pdf
project_name: A non-replicative adenovirus vaccine platform   for poultry diseases - Phase 2.

outcomes.description: This project successfully developed and tested an innovative non-replicative human adenovirus vector vaccine for Newcastle Disease (ND) in poultry, progressing from vaccine development in Phase I to dose optimization, proof-of-concept finalization, and manufacturing process development in Phase II. The research team produced multiple adenovirus-based vaccines expressing F and HN antigens, achieving 80-100% protection rates in chicken experiments through intranasal delivery at optimized doses, and developed both liquid (stable for 24 weeks at 4°C) and lyophilized formulations with minimal titer loss. Key innovations included leveraging cell culture technologies rather than expensive imported hen eggs, developing Standard Operating Procedures and regulatory documentation for vaccine registration in Ethiopia, and conducting successful technology transfer to the National Veterinary Institute (NVI) in Ethiopia with hands-on training for scientists from Ethiopia and Tunisia. The project demonstrated proof of concept for a cost-effective, safer vaccine platform that addresses the critical economic burden of Newcastle Disease on small-holder farmers in Sub-Saharan Africa, while building local vaccine development and manufacturing capabilities.

This knowledge sharing strengthened the capacity of diverse stakeholders to make relevant decisions promoting efficient use of resources dedicated to developing the livestock sector while reducing disease-related losses.

project_name: Improvement of Theileria parva sporozoite vaccine against East Coast Fever

outcomes.description: This project involved developing and testing innovative approaches to improve the Theileria parva sporozoite vaccine against East Coast Fever (ECF), a critical livestock disease. The project focused on innovative ways of producing vaccines and strategies for effective vaccine manufacturing processes, including laboratory development work conducted over an initial 30-month period. While some interesting results were produced through this development and testing work, the project did not meet all its key objectives and was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and challenges in adopting recommended methodologies (such as the in vitro assay). The project served as an important learning experience for the LVIF Animal Health team regarding risk mitigation approaches in product development, highlighting the need for more ambitious strategies beyond laboratory work, stronger initial milestones, more frequent monitoring, and consideration of all aspects of product development including manufacturing and registration requirements.

At the programmatic level, the LVIF Animal Health team developed capacity to integrate gender and other cross-cutting elements more systematically across their portfolio of projects, moving beyond a project-by-project approach. outcomes.description: Six female post-doctoral researchers from low- and middle-income countries developed and tested multiple climate and food system innovations for veterinary vaccine development and diagnostics over 11-month fellowships. Key innovations included: a novel MALDI-TOF MS-based diagnostic and strain-typing method for bovine pathogens (Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus agalactiae) that can be adapted for other veterinary and human pathogens; a bacteriophage-based multivalent vaccine for Salmonella in poultry to address circulating serovars in Kenyan farms; pathogen surveillance methods and ACE2 host receptor diversity data for non-human primates relevant to zoonotic disease monitoring; a nanoparticle-based Tilapia Lake Virus vaccine for aquaculture; plant-produced Newcastle Disease virus-like particles for poultry; and immunopeptidomics approaches for tropical theileriosis vaccines. These innovations were developed through collaborative research with local and international mentors, with fellows working in their home institutions to address veterinary health challenges affecting smallholder farmers and livestock producers in their respective countries. The project also resulted in equipment procurement (including a nanopore sequencer), multiple publications and presentations, patent applications, and follow-on research funding for continued innovation development.

project_name: Engineered Vaccines against Hemorrhagic   Septicemia in Ruminants - Phase 2

outcomes.description: This project successfully developed and tested an engineered recombinant protein vaccine (HS-PmSLP/TpbA hybrid antigen, later refined to PmSLP as the primary antigen) against hemorrhagic septicemia in ruminants caused by Pasteurella multocida. The vaccine achieved proof-of-concept with up to 100% protection against P. multocida serotypes B and E in cattle, demonstrated long-term efficacy (high antibody titers for at least 18 months post-immunization), and represents the first recombinant protein vaccine suitable for the African market. The innovation involved conducting challenge experiments at NVI Ethiopia (transitioning from homologous to heterologous challenge models to better predict farm-level protection), testing immune responses in calves as young as 3 months in Canada, filing a patent application, and training graduate students (2 Master's and 2 PhD students). outcomes.description: The project successfully developed and tested an innovative public-private partnership (PPP) franchising model for livestock vaccine delivery in pastoral areas of Ethiopia, directly involving vulnerable pastoral communities in piloting this new service delivery approach. Key achievements included: training 106 Community Animal Health Workers (CAHWs) from pastoral communities to operate under the PPP model; supporting the National Veterinary Institute (NVI) in establishing PANVAC-certified CCPP vaccine production capabilities that produced over 1 million doses; and implementing a vaccination program that reached 333,000 goats across four districts with 89.3% coverage, demonstrating the economic viability of private sector involvement with franchisee income exceeding government operational budgets by five times. outcomes.description: This project developed innovative vaccine technologies against avian influenza targeting the needs of smallholder poultry farmers in vulnerable regions. outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion by conducting a gendered analysis of household food purchasing and preparation patterns in South Africa and Ghana. The analysis revealed critical gender differences: households where men were responsible for food purchasing consumed more meat, fast food, salty snacks, and ready-to-eat meals (linked to higher non-communicable disease risks), while households where women were responsible consumed more sugar and home-baked bread. These findings generated actionable insights demonstrating that health promotion and behavior change interventions must be tailored to each gender to be effective. The project also trained the next generation of researchers with a gender lens, supporting 1 female post-doctoral researcher, 3 PhD students (including two females), and 2 master's students (one female), thereby building institutional capacity for gender-responsive research in food systems and health.

outcomes.description: The project established exemplary South-South collaboration and peer-learning networks among researchers and field thought leaders across seven countries in eastern and southern Africa, catalyzing a community of practice in the previously under-researched field of non-communicable disease (NCD) prevention and fiscal policies in Sub-Saharan Africa. outcomes.description: The project engaged vulnerable communities, informal food retailers, and local government stakeholders in co-creating and testing multiple food system innovations aimed at addressing diet-related NCDs. Food System Committees were piloted and designed to be embedded in existing community structures (such as Community Health Committees in Kenya) through participatory action research, with mandates to identify neighborhood-scale food systems interventions. The project developed and tested an innovative approach to understanding healthy food markets beyond supermarkets by attempting to engage informal food traders, which is particularly significant given rising food costs. A notable innovation was the development and testing of food voucher systems that shifted from major supermarkets to smaller neighborhood retailers like Flash, allowing vulnerable communities to maintain shopping habits, avoid crowded transport, and support local retailers. Local government and community stakeholders were supported to utilize locally derived research evidence to develop action plans and interventions for preventing diet-related NCDs.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity for gender equality and inclusion through multiple approaches. The research team, which was majority women (6 out of 11 researchers including the PI Dr. Jane Battersby and other senior researchers), built understanding of how to engage vulnerable communities in food systems research and governance, particularly focusing on low-income urban women as key food decision makers. The project conducted research on the complex drivers of urban household food practices among women, who have higher rates of diet-related non-communicable disease risk factors such as obesity, and investigated their lived experiences with food consumption patterns and food environments. The work generated important findings that diet quality is not a high priority for low-income urban women and that food is viewed as expenditure, comfort, care, culture bearer, and other complex things, leading to recommendations for new approaches to diet-related messaging and new forms of inclusion of community voices in health messaging. The ultimate aim was to empower women to become more influential actors in the urban food governance space.

project_name: Evaluating the impacts of gender integration on agriculture, food and nutrition security and gender equality outcomes

outcomes.description: Smallholder farmers in Kenya were actively involved in developing, testing, and piloting the Gender Transformative Farmer Field and Business Schools (GT-FFBS) model, an innovation that integrated gender, nutrition, and improved agricultural practices into conventional farmer field schools. The project expanded from an initial target of 20 farmer groups to 89 groups establishing demonstration trials, with 1,545 farmers (64% women and 36% men) directly engaged in testing and adopting specific agricultural innovations including ridging for potato planting, stringing of garden peas, improved spacing methods, and kitchen gardens. A Participatory Performance Tracker assessment revealed that 92% of respondents (93% female and 7% male) adopted the demonstrated practices due to higher yields, reduced labor requirements, and improved household income and food security. The project also developed 32 farmer trainers (14 female and 19 male) who gained skills to train fellow farmers, promoting sustainability of the innovation. This innovation generated evidence demonstrating the benefits of integrating gender transformative approaches into agricultural programming for improving productivity, women's empowerment, nutrition security, and gender equality.
outcomes.geography: Kenya, Nyandarua County, Kenya
outcomes.target_population: Smallholder farmers (1,545 total: 64% women and 36% men), vulnerable communities, women smallholder farmers who constitute 75% of Kenya's agricultural labor force, 32 farmer trainers (14 female and 19 male), policy makers and development practitioners
quotes: As a result of the project's capacity building sessions on improved agricultural practises, marketing, gender and nutrition, the project demonstrated evidence that favors the farmers field school model in general and makes a strong case for integrating gender and nutrition components through the Gender Transformative Farmer Field and Business Schools model.

Results from a Participatory Performance Tracker (PPT) assessment revealed that overall 92% of the respondents (7% male and 93% female) were motivated from the demonstrations and adopted ridging potato planting due to higher yields and less labor requirements during weeding and harvesting as well as better yields that contributed to income and for household consumption.

This project contributed to the body of evidence important for policy makers and development practitioners by investigating and sharing results on how the gender transformative approaches of incorporating gender modules to the conventional farmer field and business schools' modules can benefit both agriculture productivity, empowerment of women and gender equality.

outcomes.description: Smallholder farmers adopted multiple innovations and practices that promote climate resilience and sustainable food systems as a result of the project's capacity building sessions. outcomes.outcome_type: Sustained Gender Equality and Inclusion Transformations
outcomes.description: The project achieved sustained, transformational changes in gender equality by addressing root causes of inequity in Kenya's food system, particularly inequalities in resource access, control, and women's participation in decision-making. Through Gender Transformative Farmer Field and Business Schools (GT-FFBS) that included gender dialogues and training involving both men and women, the proportion of women making most or all decisions in staple grain farming increased from 67% to 79% between baseline and endline. Significant changes in joint decision-making emerged, with 54% of women in the gender transformative group reporting being consulted by their spouses on household income, expenditure, marketing, and crop selection, and 25% of women reporting increased ability and confidence to provide input on productive resources. The interventions also led to reduced cases of gender-based violence and improved family dynamics, though challenges remained such as women's limited ownership of land and other productive resources despite having access.

outcomes.description: The project engaged consumers including adults and children in testing and assessing the effectiveness of different front-of-package (FOP) food labeling systems through multiple survey methodologies, including in-person and online assessments to determine the most suitable FOP labeling system for implementation. The multidisciplinary research teams developed and tested innovative methodological tools including Discrete Choice Experiments (DEC) to assess purchase intent for different FOP label models, and novel use of big data for food price analysis comparing costs of healthy versus unhealthy diets. Through this consumer-involved testing and development process, the project contributed to implementing food consumption information and guidance systems—representing innovative food policy tools—in two Latin American countries where food labeling and quality is of special sensitivity. The research provided local original scientific evidence demonstrating the effectiveness of the warning FOP labeling model, with results directly informing and supporting the approval of new FOP food label policies at national and regional levels.

project_name: Coherence of food and agricultural policies with non-communicable disease prevention in South Africa

outcomes.description: This pioneering project in Africa developed and tested an innovative methodological approach for analyzing policy coherence between agri-food systems and health policies aimed at addressing diet-related non-communicable diseases. The project employed both quantitative and qualitative research methods to analyze over 60 agri-food and health policies in South Africa, representing a novel approach for the region. Through this innovation testing process, the project generated new knowledge demonstrating lack of coherence across agricultural, trade, health, and related policies, identifying inadequate multisectoral coordination. The project simultaneously strengthened research capacity by assembling a team of mid- and early-career researchers who developed collective research skills in areas including value chain analysis while achieving the project's goals.
outcomes.geography: South Africa
outcomes.target_population: Mid- and early-career researchers, including the principal investigator and team members who gained expertise in value chain analysis and policy coherence research methodologies
quotes: To the best of our knowledge, this project is a pioneering effort in Africa to employ both quantitative and qualitative approaches to investigate the level and causes of incoherence between health and agri-food policies.

outcomes.description: This research project generated new knowledge demonstrating the lack of coherence between agri-food and health policies in South Africa in the context of preventing diet-related noncommunicable diseases, marking the first study of its kind in Africa. The research findings identified specific problems including policy incoherence, lack of inter-sectoral and inter-departmental coordination, and insufficient incentives for fruit and vegetable production and consumption. The study proposed concrete policy solutions including a multi-stakeholder approach involving government and civil society, tax incentives, and subsidies aimed at improving market competitiveness and accessibility of fruits and vegetables. These findings have the potential to influence policymakers in South Africa to enact cross-sectoral policy changes that will enhance access to fruits and vegetables, especially for low-income communities, contributing to the reduction of the high burden of noncommunicable diseases in the country.

outcomes.description: This project produced high-quality, southern-based research evidence on food systems, policy coherence, and nutrition in South Africa, representing the first research of its kind in Africa to examine the relationship between agri-food policies and NCD prevention. The project analyzed over 60 agri-food and health policies (63 total) and generated new knowledge demonstrating lack of coherence and inadequate multisectoral coordination across these policies. Research outputs included quantitative and qualitative findings on fruit and vegetable consumption patterns among different socio-economic groups and genders, value-chain analysis showing insufficient incentives for production and marketing of indigenous fruits and vegetables, and identification of barriers to adequate consumption including cost, affordability, and negative attitudes toward indigenous produce. The project produced multiple peer-reviewed journal articles and publications, including studies on farm production diversification, dietary diversity among subsistence farming households, and the role of information technologies in fruit and vegetable consumption.

outcomes.description: The project engaged multiple stakeholders including vulnerable communities, smallholder farmers, and women's groups in developing, testing, and implementing integrated packages of interventions to address food system leverage points using participatory methods including Group Model Building. Key innovations tested included the 'best buys' approach for preparing affordable healthy meals using commonly available foods, and fifteen small grants providing gender-responsive technical support to local farmers and women's groups to implement agricultural activities for food security and income generation, with some participating farmer groups achieving certification for quality standards and securing bulk supply opportunities. The project also developed and tested simple health messaging tools in collaboration with grassroots organizations including women's groups and faith-based organizations. Additionally, the project tested enhanced laboratory equipment and capacity to analyze sugar, salt, and fat content of food products, which revealed that 40% of products tested contained trans fats and contributed to policy advocacy. Through the Women's Farmers Academy, 380 women received training in entrepreneurship, financial literacy, marketing, digital connectivity, and leadership skills.

outcomes.outcome_type: Improved Understanding of Climate and Food System Issues and Policy Solutions
outcomes.description: Decision-makers across government, regional organizations, and the private sector gained improved understanding of climate-related food system issues and evidence-based policy solutions to address unhealthy diets and non-communicable diseases in the CARICOM region. Government officials including the Minister of Health Jamaica used project evidence on trans fats (identifying that 40% of products tested contained trans fats) to advance trans fat reduction/elimination policies, leading to successful decisions to legislate the prohibition of partially hydrogenated oils by December 2023 and eliminate them by December 2025, with learnings incorporated into Jamaica's 2022-2030 National Strategic NCD plan and Parish NCD plans. The CARICOM Secretariat representatives and ministers of health, education, and agriculture improved their understanding through evidence on trans fats, salt, and sugar that contributed to ministerial parliamentary debates on food system policies. Private sector stakeholders, including importers of partially hydrogenated oils and food industry partners, developed improved understanding of trans fat elimination as a policy solution, with positive responsiveness emerging during dissemination meetings including the Trans Fat Forum convened by the Ministry of Health Jamaica.

outcomes.description: The project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate-resilient food systems, nutrition security, and public health in the CARICOM region. Through Group Model Building methodology, the project generated knowledge on cross-cutting socio-economic factors impacting healthy diet consumption, identifying that cost and convenience—rather than health—were major drivers of consumer food choices, along with climate change impacts on food imports and the need for gender-sensitive food and nutrition policies. Multiple peer-reviewed journal articles were published in open access formats, including studies on systems approaches to unhealthy eating, COVID-19 impacts on food security, comparative cost of diets for low-income families, and integrated food systems approaches for healthy diets. The research produced practical tools and datasets, including analysis showing 40% of tested food products contained trans fats, baseline reviews of food and nutrition policies assessing gender equality coherence, and evidence on leverage points for system-wide interventions. Additional research outputs included a Master of Science thesis on school feeding value chains, policy briefs, advocacy materials, and a dedicated website (onecaribbeanhealth.org) serving as a repository for knowledge dissemination.

project_name: Scaling up farming through public-private linkages to improve rural women’s income

outcomes.description: Rural women smallholder farmers in Ghana were actively involved in developing, co-creating, piloting, and testing multiple climate and food system innovations including poultry enterprises, eggplant gardening, nutrition-sensitive agriculture interventions, and gender transformative approaches. The project successfully tested co-creation of knowledge with 165 participating women beneficiaries through an innovative case study approach where participants themselves identified strategies that successful women entrepreneurs utilized versus challenges faced by less successful women. Gender transformative approaches were tested and proven effective, including negotiations with rural banks that resulted in reduced interest rates and over 90% loan repayment rates, ultimately leading to policy changes favoring business opportunities with women entrepreneurs. The project also tested nutrition-sensitive intervention packages through three key pathways (food production, income generation, and women's empowerment), demonstrating positive impacts on dietary diversity scores, food security levels, and empowerment outcomes, though COVID-19 restrictions impeded full integration of these tested approaches into permanent district and local programs.

outcomes.target_population: 165 women smallholder farmers and agripreneurs in rural Ghana (including 132 women focused on poultry and 33 women cultivating eggplants), their children and household members, local institutions including rural banks and government departments, interdisciplinary researchers (1 Ph.D. student from McGill University, 4 master's students from University of Ghana, several local young women research assistants), and community members in project locations

outcomes.description: The project established and strengthened multiple equitable, multi-stakeholder partnerships involving women farmers, government departments (including the National Board for Small Scale Industries and Department of Agriculture), local institutions, private sector actors (particularly rural banks), and research organizations from McGill University and the University of Ghana. Through collaborative planning, design, and implementation of intervention packages, these partnerships led to mutual learnings and ensured community voices were integrated throughout the process. The Business Advisory Committee of the National Board for Small Scale Industries engaged directly with project women farmers and facilitated their access to government relief credit to mitigate COVID-19 impacts on small and medium enterprises. The partnerships resulted in policy changes, including a rural bank reducing interest rates and changing policies to favor women entrepreneurs, and government departments adopting the project's loan concept to pilot poultry interventions in new communities. The frequent, equitable collaboration between researchers from both universities during the pandemic demonstrated shared decision-making and strengthened international research partnerships for delivering innovations on nutrition-sensitive agriculture and women's empowerment.

outcomes.description: Climate adaptation and food system actors in Ghana adopted multiple innovations that promoted climate resilience and nutrition-sensitive agriculture at scale. The local Department of Agriculture adopted the project's loan concept to pilot a poultry intervention in a new community using their own institutional funds, demonstrating uptake of project-developed practices by government institutions. The National Board for Small Scale Industries changed institutional behavior by engaging with project beneficiaries and facilitating their access to governmental relief credit. At the farmer level, 132 women agripreneurs adopted and sustained poultry production practices, selling over 1.8 million eggs worth approximately US$180,000, while 33 women adopted eggplant cultivation, selling over 62,000 kg valued at approximately US$124,000, representing concrete behavioral change and sustained practice adoption by smallholder farmers beyond direct project activities.

outcomes.description: The project successfully developed and tested Mbiotisho, an innovative smartphone-based mobile application for collecting real-time nutrition and health data, involving vulnerable communities throughout the development and testing process. The app uses audio, icons, photos, interactive voice responses, and games to enable data collection by largely illiterate caregivers, with 189 study participants achieving an 83% submission rate over 54 weeks during field testing. Women caregivers from diverse communities—including those with high illiteracy levels—were directly involved in piloting, testing, and providing feedback that informed app deployment, with the tool rated as simple to understand (88%), faster (75%), and time-saving (63%). The versatile innovation was tested and adapted across multiple contexts including child health and dietary monitoring, drought surveillance, HIV/AIDS monitoring, and child development studies in marginalized communities. The project fully met its objective to develop and test cost-effective, scalable technologies for improving high-resolution dietary, nutrition, and health data collection, with formal ethics approval granted and validation conducted through comparison with traditional methods.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion across multiple actors through research and institutional integration of gender-responsive approaches. A cross-cutting study in Kenya generated actionable insights on gender dynamics of smartphone use for data collection, revealing that while 94% of women participants had access to mobile phones, only 53% had control, and identifying critical factors such as the need to involve men to avoid household conflict and the value of token payments for family buy-in. These findings informed the deployment of the ICT-based data collection platform, which was explicitly designed to address women's capacity to access and use nutrition monitoring tools, including features operable by largely illiterate individuals through icons, photos, interactive voice responses, and games. The gender-responsive approach developed through this project has been institutionalized and is now a normal part of the implementing organization's gender equality and inclusion framework, providing a model for future initiatives in the region.

outcomes.description: Women farmers and vulnerable communities in the Niger Delta region were directly involved in developing, testing, and implementing community-based climate adaptation initiatives across 10 rural target communities. The project generated knowledge that guided pilot intervention activities championed by women farmers, focusing on testing affordable and effective adaptation strategies responsive to local needs. This included the development of multiple innovations such as publications, policy documents, tools, and training materials that were co-created through participatory processes involving community members. Gender exercises promoting feminist methodologies were embedded in training guides, and Community Project Implementation Committees (CPICs) were established to support women-led adaptation efforts. The innovations and tools developed through the project demonstrated impact on communities beyond expected results, with communities testing climate-smart agriculture approaches, adaptation strategies like early planting and crop rotation, and new community organizing models that promoted gender equality alongside climate resilience.

outcomes.description: The project established and strengthened equitable partnerships and networks at multiple levels to deliver innovations and share knowledge on climate resilience and gender equality. A network of gender advocates outside the organization was developed, with women farmers from 10 communities organizing themselves into committees supported on the ground by ICWA and CPED. Community Project Implementation Committees (CPICs) were successfully established in 10 communities within the Delta, resulting in about 100 men supporting the inclusion of women's voices in community leadership structures. These partnerships emphasized equity and women's leadership, with women in several communities stepping up to take leadership roles—for example, in Uzere community, five women became part of the 11-member community development committee (CDC) with two nominated to leadership positions, whereas women had previously been excluded from key decision-making organs.

outcomes.description: The Centre for Population and Environmental Development (CPED) successfully secured a grant from the United States Institute of Peace (USIP) for promoting community-embedded youth peacebuilding and conflict mitigation in Nigeria's Niger Delta region. This additional funding was mobilized as a direct result of CPED's enhanced capacity in gender-transformative research and programming, which was built through IDRC support over the past 10 years, including through the Gender at Work (G@W) program. The USIP grant proposal incorporated key research questions about the root causes and drivers of Niger Delta conflicts, specifically addressing the role of youth and the importance of social and gender inequalities in peacebuilding experiences. CPED team members' increased ability to embed feminist and gender-transformative language in discussions, proposals, and trainings was explicitly cited as a factor that hugely influenced the selection of this proposal by USIP.

Team members gained enhanced skills in integrating gender perspectives into research and monitoring and evaluation processes, applying gender lenses to their work, and embedding feminist/gender transformative language in discussions, proposals, and trainings. outcomes.description: The project produced extensive southern-based research and evidence addressing critical knowledge gaps on climate resilience, food systems, and gender equality in the Niger Delta region. Key research outputs included empirical studies on climate vulnerability and economic conditions of rural households, gender-based assessments of climate-change adaptation strategies, COVID-19 impact surveys of 2,000 farmers (600 food producers, 600 food marketers, and 800 households) examining disruptions to local food production and informal markets, and multiple policy briefs on pandemic impacts. The project generated outstanding numbers of publications, policy documents, tools, and training materials on the under-resourced research agenda connecting climate change, gender inequalities, and conflict. Research findings documented chronic food insecurity across ecological zones, gender-differentiated adoption of adaptation strategies, women's constraints in accessing resources and decision-making, and significant climate-related agricultural losses, providing crucial evidence base for development planning in this fragile context.

outcomes.description: Smallholder farmers in the Niger Delta region adopted multiple climate adaptation practices and agricultural innovations as a result of the project's training and capacity-building activities. A majority of farmers employed early planting, crop rotation, and minimum tillage as strategies to combat climate change challenges. Among women farmers specifically, 92.9% changed their planting dates, 89.6% adopted early maturing varieties, 77.9% adopted pest resistant varieties, and 82.5% adopted diversification practices. These behavioral changes represented concrete shifts in agricultural decision-making and practices to promote climate resilience among vulnerable farming communities facing flooding, wildfires, and other climate-related impacts.

outcomes.description: The project achieved sustained transformational changes in gender equality and inclusion across 10 communities in Nigeria's Niger Delta region by addressing root causes of gender inequity through institutional reforms and long-term norm changes. Women gained significant decision-making power, with five women joining an 11-member Community Development Committee (CDC) in Uzere community (up from zero prior to intervention), including two in leadership positions, marking a fundamental shift in community governance structures. Structural barriers to resource access were reduced when 15 vulnerable women (majority widows) in Amajomata community were allocated farmland without payment, addressing the longstanding constraint of restricted land accessibility for women farmers. Community men shifted attitudes and began supporting women's leadership in climate-change adaptation, with approximately 100 men actively supporting the inclusion of women's voices in leadership structures. These changes represent sustained transformations rooted in capacity building on gender equality and equity, feminist methodologies embedded in training guides, and the development of networks of gender advocates organized into community committees.

outcomes.description: The MIGRANTAS project produced extensive high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on climate resilience, gender, migration, and food systems in the context of environmental degradation and climate change impacts. The research generated multiple scientific outputs including peer-reviewed journal articles and book chapters that examined the intersection of gender, migration, and climate change through an innovative intersectional approach, demonstrating that migrant women's unpaid care work extends to environmental and nature care work and highlighting their agency as climate change adaptation leaders. The project successfully achieved its objective of enhancing knowledge about strategies and resources of women migrant workers facing differentiated climate change impacts in the Reconquista River Basin, producing evidence through participatory action-research that made visible local knowledge about climate change dimensions from a southern, gendered perspective. Key research outputs included socioenvironmental impact mapping studies, data on COVID-19 pandemic impacts on vulnerable migrant populations, and analyses of how social factors such as class, ethnicity, and gender interact with climate-based realities to determine migrant women's control over resources and decision-making. This research filled a vital gap in the literature on the care economy and its link to climate change adaptation, and the outputs are being disseminated to broader audiences including connections to other initiatives focused on waste-pickers and care work.

outcomes.description: The MIGRANTAS project achieved significant policy adoption and implementation at both municipal and provincial levels in Argentina. The project created a knowledge platform that led to the development and adoption of a Municipal Ordinance for the Democratic Management of the Caring City in San Martin, which incorporates gender perspective as a guiding principle for policies covering housing, habitat, and city rights. As a result of this ordinance, the Municipality established the Municipal Institute for the Development of Habitat and Housing in January 2021, which is responsible for implementing the ordinance and promoting participation among all actors in the territory. The project also had direct impact on infrastructure decisions, with the socioenvironmental impact mapping study serving as the basis for the piping of the Eva Perón stream by the Provincial Organization for Social and Urban Integration (OPISU) in collaboration with the provincial council of the Reconquista River Basin (COMIREC). These policy achievements demonstrate substantial adoption of social innovations by local and provincial governments that contribute to public awareness and debate around socio-environmental problems and the role of women migrant workers in addressing climate change.

project_name: Alien Invasive Fruit Flies in Southern Africa: Implementation of a Sustainable IPM Program to Combat their Menaces

outcomes.description: The project involved vulnerable smallholder farmers in developing, co-creating, piloting, and testing multiple climate-resilient innovations for fruit fly management across Southern Africa. Key innovations tested included: (1) IPM technologies such as host marking pheromones (glutathione and glutamic acid), biological control using parasitoids (F. arisanus and D. longicaudata) with field releases and post-release evaluation, mass trapping, protein baits, and sanitation methods; (2) tree grafting techniques for improved mango varieties using indigenous drought-resistant rootstock, which farmers are currently applying; and (3) simple basket dryers made of polyethylene nets for mango preservation and value addition to reduce post-harvest losses. The project reached the early stages of proving and fine-tuning IPM technology use with meaningful farmer participation, demonstrating that IPM techniques reduced fruit fly infestation losses from 80% to 30% and that dried mango could be sold for 8 times more than fresh fruit in some countries. Women farmers were particularly engaged in co-creating the drying innovation as a response to COVID-19 market disruptions, which reduced their workload while improving household income and nutrition security.

outcomes.description: Up to 4,075 mango farmers (62% women) were trained as trainers on IPM techniques, and an additional 11,131 farmers (47% women) were directly reached through farmer field days; all received IPM starter packs and actively used IPM technologies (mass trapping, protein baits, sanitation, biological pesticides) throughout the project cycle, representing a significant shift from previous practices. Farmers adopted innovative post-harvest solutions including simple basket dryers made of polyethylene nets to reduce losses and add value, with dried mangoes selling for up to 8 times more than fresh fruit in Zambia and Zimbabwe. The IPM adoption reduced crop losses from 80% to 30%, increased household annual income from mango crops (from 7% to 18% in Zambia), and demonstrated effectiveness across multiple crops including guavas and Cucurbita species. As a result of project research, farmers increased mango tree stands and adopted grafting techniques using improved varieties with indigenous drought-resistant rootstock, promoting climate resilience. Women farmers formed savings groups (stokvels) from their produce income, using proceeds to purchase food in bulk, acquire livestock, and open bank accounts, representing broader behavioral changes toward sustainable and inclusive food systems.

IDRC itself gained reinforced understanding of the value of integrated evidence-based approaches that prioritize healthy, affordable diets while keeping greenhouse gas emissions within sustainable limits. The three national research teams from Argentina, Brazil, and Chile, along with their partner constituencies, achieved stronger understanding of governance challenges, knowledge gaps, and policy gaps related to food systems, and developed agendas for action with specific policy recommendations. In Chile, the project engaged senators through working tables at the National Senate, resulting in specific recommendations including strengthening institutions, regulations for carbon sequestering, restrictions on unhealthy food access, and funding for R&D projects on healthy and climate-friendly food systems. National dialogues in Argentina and Brazil involved researchers, advocacy players, decision-makers, government officials, and civil society leaders in discussions that bridged public health nutrition, climate change, and sustainable development fields.
outcomes.geography: Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Latin America and the Caribbean
outcomes.target_population: Decision-makers including government officials, senators (particularly Chilean Senate Committee for the Challenges of the Future, Science, Technology and Innovation), local authorities, program managers, donors, civil society leaders, private sector decision-makers, researchers, advocacy players, multidisciplinary research teams, and IDRC as a key decision-making organization
quotes: In Chile, the project supported a series of working tables at the National Senate involving different actors and with the engagement of several senators. Relevant recommendations emerged as the need to strengthen institutions to advance a sustainable food consumption and production agenda, strengthen regulations including increasing economic incentives to carbon sequestering in soil, increased funding for sustainable production initiatives, regulations leading to restricting access to unhealthy food, economic tools to decrease the consumption of unhealthy food, and funding to R&D projects on healthy and climate friendly food systems.

It made a significant contribution to IDRC's strategic objective on knowledge for largescale positive change by enabling a stronger understanding of the governance challenges, knowledge and policy gaps of food systems and convening key constituencies in the region to discuss the Agenda for Action.

outcomes.description: Three national multidisciplinary research teams from Argentina, Brazil, and Chile produced extensive southern-based research and evidence outputs on healthy, sustainable, and climate-friendly food systems. Key research outputs included final technical reports for each country, literature reviews, policy reviews, stakeholder analyses, political economy analyses, and agendas for action that consolidated evidence on governance challenges, knowledge gaps, and policy gaps affecting food systems. The project significantly expanded the field of research in the Latin America and Caribbean region by bridging public health nutrition, climate change, and sustainable development dimensions that had previously been addressed separately. Research outputs also included policy briefs, brochures, a web platform (Feeding Policies), position papers, and extensive media engagement (67 media outlets contacted, 24 media pieces published), successfully positioning the sustainable food systems agenda at national, regional, and international levels. These knowledge products provided evidence on critical issues including the interface between healthy and climate-friendly food systems, greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture and livestock, and the political-institutional determinants affecting food system transitions.

project_name: Policy foundations, country dialogues, and analytics for food system transformative integrated policy in Rwanda, Malawi, and Ghana

outcomes.description: The project developed and tested the Food System Transformative Integrated Policy (FS-TIP) initiative and accompanying food systems diagnostic toolkit, which provides a comprehensive methodological guide for conducting landscape analysis and diagnostics of food systems. The toolkit was piloted and applied in three African countries (Rwanda, Ghana, and Malawi) through stakeholder mapping, policy mapping, and indicator identification processes. This innovative approach and toolkit has already been scaled up for use in multiple other countries beyond the original three, demonstrating its adaptability and utility as a tool for policy development tailored to each country's context and priorities. The FS-TIP process contributed critical inputs to the UN Food Systems Summit 2021 dialogues that led to political commitments and equipped government leaders with tools for developing transformative and integrated food systems policies.

project_name: - CIFOR-Shea Parklands

outcomes.description: The project established and strengthened multiple equitable partnerships and networks at national, regional, and international levels to advance climate-resilient shea parkland management and sustainable food systems. Key partnerships included collaboration between international organizations (CIFOR, Bioversity International, Wageningen University Research) and southern institutions (Université Nazi Boni, Institut de l'environnement et de recherches agricoles), with inclusive working approaches that gave local scientists lead authorship and data control. The project strengthened the national Multi-Stakeholder Initiative (Table Filière Karité) and positioned it within the Ministry of Environment's portfolio, while the National Shea Forum brought together 180 representatives from all actor groups in the shea supply chain. The project fostered multi-ministerial collaboration between the Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Agriculture, participated in the Regional Shea Alliance and Global Shea Alliance platforms, and was recognized at the UN Food Systems Summit as an exemplary model of IDRC-Montpellier Systems of Research collaboration. These partnerships supported capacity building (including successful supervision of 4 MSc students), co-development of national strategy documents, and participatory action plans for inclusive shea park management in local communes.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity to promote gender equality and inclusion in shea parkland management and climate adaptation through multiple approaches. The research team developed enhanced skills and methods by examining gender-based differences in shea tree valuation and identifying strategies for equitable and sustainable management of shea resources. The project identified vulnerabilities and opportunities for rural women shea producers in the context of climate change, providing science-based evidence to support policy and governance reforms. Additionally, the project team demonstrated improved capacity by fully embracing a do-no-harm approach to field research and establishing participatory opt-in/opt-out procedures in response to ethical concerns about women's participation, reflecting strengthened institutional processes for integrating gender considerations into research practices.

outcomes.outcome_type: Improved Understanding of Climate and Food System Issues and Policy Solutions
outcomes.description: Decision-makers across government ministries in Burkina Faso (Ministry of Environment, Green Economy and Climate Change; Ministry of Agriculture) gained improved understanding of climate-related risks, food system vulnerabilities, and policy solutions for sustainable shea parkland management and women's economic empowerment. This was evidenced by concrete policy actions including: co-drafting a new National Strategy for the valorization of shea parklands that reclassified shea from tree to agricultural crop for better protection and improved employment conditions for women; transferring shea parklands supervision to the Ministry of Agriculture jointly with MEEVCC; endorsement of a 'Call to Action' by 180 representatives across the shea supply chain at the National Shea Forum aligned with Burkina Faso's National Climate Change Adaptation Plan; and the creation of guidance documents and participatory action plans that now serve as the knowledge basis for improved governance. outcomes.description: The project achieved significant policy reforms in shea parklands governance in Burkina Faso at both national and local levels. At the national level, the project successfully advocated for a historic institutional change: shea parklands were placed under joint supervision of the Ministry of Agriculture and MEEVCC for the first time, with implementation of the transfer from the Ministry of Environment currently underway. The project co-drafted a new National Strategy for the valorization of shea parklands (Second National Shea Development Strategy 2021-2025) and a guidance document that is now actively used by the national government as the knowledge basis for improved governance and management of shea parklands and value chains, aligned with Burkina Faso's National Climate Change Adaptation Plan. At the local level, the project contributed to the development of participatory action plans for inclusive shea park management in two communes (Sapouy and Bougnounou-Nébiélianayou), and successfully influenced the national Multi-Stakeholder Initiative (Table Filière Karité/Table de Concertation sur la Filiere de Karite) to include stronger representation of women in the shea value chain. The National Shea Forum (June 2021, 180 participants) resulted in a 'Call to Action' that positioned shea within MEEVCC's portfolio and envisaged greater support for national parkland restoration programs, domestication and genetic development of shea trees, and the potential introduction of an export tax to support parkland regeneration.

outcomes.description: Government officials and policymakers in Tanzania gained improved understanding of non-communicable disease (NCD) risks and fiscal policy solutions through evidence on sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) taxation. Decision-makers including government ministers, Ministry of Health representatives, and Tanzania Commission for Science and Technology officials learned that a 20% SSB tax could reduce obesity by approximately 7% overall (6.6% in the model, with 12.9% reduction in adult males and 5.2% in adult females) and nearly double government revenue from excise taxes on SSBs. The findings made a strong impression at a dissemination workshop, leading to a special invitation to present in the Swahili Policy Brief (distributed to all government ministers), positioning the evidence to influence policy reforms for NCD prevention. Policymakers also gained critical understanding that SSB taxation is not gender-neutral, with men experiencing more than twice the obesity reduction compared to women, informing considerations for complementary interventions for NCD risk prevention.

outcomes.description: The project produced the first research of its kind in Eastern Africa on the potential impact of sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) taxation on obesity prevalence in Tanzania. The research generated novel, high-quality quantitative evidence including: the economic burden of NCDs (US$1,212 per person annually, exceeding Tanzania's GDP per capita; national aggregate cost of US$349 million in 2019); a mathematical model demonstrating that a 20% SSB tax would reduce obesity by 6.6% overall (12.9% in adult males and 5.2% in adult females); projected government revenue increases of 109% to TZS 868 billion (US$372 million); and administrative implementation costs of only TZS 69,120,669 (US$29,659). The research also produced important gender-differentiated evidence, finding that SSB taxation is not gender-neutral and would have more than twice the impact on reducing obesity in men compared to women despite women having higher obesity levels. At least 2 peer-reviewed papers are anticipated to be published in open access journals, and the findings received media coverage across local Tanzanian newspapers including the Guardian, the Citizen, Nipashe, and the Daily News.

The research team demonstrated this enhanced capacity by integrating gender perspectives into their analysis, producing gender-disaggregated dietary findings that revealed differences in healthy eating patterns between women-led and men-led households. outcomes.description: This project produced the first quantitative national-level assessment of the cost of eating healthy in Kenya, generating novel, high-quality, southern-based research evidence led by the African Population and Health Research Center (APHRC). The research outputs included four manuscripts in the pipeline for publication in open access journals, a full study report, a policy brief, a video animation, a blog post, and media coverage by a major Kenyan outlet, all publicly available to enhance visibility and inform policy. A significant contribution was the gendered analysis that revealed new findings about differences in fruit and vegetable consumption patterns and associated costs between women-led and men-led households, showing that women-led households had greater adherence to WHO dietary recommendations but spent almost USD 100 more per person annually than male-led households meeting the same recommendations. This novel evidence quantifies the cost-benefit of healthy versus unhealthy foods and provides policymakers with data to inform fiscal policies such as subsidies or reduced taxes for healthier foods like fruits and vegetables, while also highlighting the need to consider gender implications in policy interventions aimed at improving the affordability of healthy diets.

outcomes.description: The project produced substantial southern-based research evidence on governance, ethics, and conflicts of interest in public health interactions with corporate actors, contributing to the emerging field of commercial determinants of health. Key research outputs included two peer-reviewed publications in Globalization and Health and International Journal of Public Health (the latter receiving second-place recognition in a special issue on market-driven forces and public health), examining attitudes toward accepting funding from for-profit organizations and the effects of conflicts of interest on health research particularly in LMICs. The project developed locally grounded but globally relevant knowledge through multiple mechanisms including a webinar series (12 webinars organized between December 2019-February 2021), two newsletters, conference presentations at six major international public health conferences, and two seed grant-funded research projects examining conflicts of interest in food/nutrition research in Ghana and corporate political activity of the food industry in Guatemala and Panama. This research addressed critical questions about private sector engagement in food systems and NCD prevention, the linkages between SDGs and public health accountability frameworks, and how commercial determinants of health frameworks can be used to understand commercial actors' influence on food system healthiness in the Global South, ultimately providing a robust evidence base to guide public health policymaking and research-for-development funding decisions.

outcomes.description: The project developed and implemented the Food Security Dashboard (FSDB), an innovative tool that provides critical stock information to the Government of Pakistan for coordinating supply and demand of essential food commodities and making decisions on movement of food from surplus to deficient districts to avoid crises. SDPI advocated for this innovation and presented it to the PM Economic Advisory Committee where it was accepted, and subsequently helped draft the Food Security Information Flow Bill to guarantee data availability and ensure the dashboard's functionality through daily data entry. This dashboard innovation represented the earliest and strongest strand of work, directly informing policy making and contributing to improvement of the country's food security policies during the COVID-19 pandemic. The innovation was recognized by government partners and exemplified how vulnerable communities could be protected through development and deployment of climate and food system tools.

outcomes.description: The project successfully established and strengthened equitable partnerships and networks between SDPI (Sustainable Development Policy Institute) and Pakistan's government to deliver innovations and share knowledge on climate resilience and food systems during the COVID-19 crisis. outcomes.description: Government actors in Pakistan adopted the Food Security Dashboard (FSDB) as an operational innovation to inform food security management and distribution decisions, with data entry guaranteed daily through the Food Security Information Flow Bill that SDPI helped draft. SDPI's influence led to increased engagement in key government bodies including the National Food Security Committee, Resource Mobilization Commission, Agriculture Transformation Plan, and National Coordination Committee on Agriculture, demonstrating sustained adoption of evidence-based approaches to climate-resilient food systems.

outcomes.description: The project involved 188 smallholder farmers across Algeria's three main agro-ecological zones (arid, semi-arid, and sub-humid) in developing, testing, and piloting mycorrhiza-based biostimulant innovations for climate-resilient agriculture. Researchers isolated five new mycorrhizal strains endemic to Algerian soil, produced over 1,100 kg of mycorrhizae, and conducted greenhouse experimentation followed by extensive on-farm trials across different vegetable crops including olive trees, potatoes, tomatoes, and peppers. The testing demonstrated yield increases ranging from 32% to 55% depending on the crop, validating the effectiveness of this bio-fertilization technology as an alternative to chemical fertilizers. The project also conceptualized and piloted business models to facilitate large-scale adoption of the innovation, working with private sector actors to assess technical and economic viability for both producers and agricultural users. Farmer testimonial videos documented their experiences testing this natural fertilizer innovation, providing evidence of community involvement in co-creating and validating this climate and food system solution.

outcomes.description: The project established multiple equitable partnerships and networks to deliver mycorrhizal innovation for climate-resilient agriculture in Algeria. A South-North research collaboration was formed between Collège de Maisonneuve (Canada) and University of Blida (Algeria), with Algerian researchers leading practical implementation using local resources and soils. These partnerships were showcased at an IDRC flagship knowledge sharing event in Morocco (May 2024) that promoted private-public sector collaboration and South-South cooperation for climate-resilient agriculture in North Africa.

project_name: Savings for health: Harnessing rotating   savings and credit associations to improve healthy   food choices.

outcomes.description: This project engaged women-led grocery stokvels (rotating savings and credit associations) in South Africa in developing and testing innovative approaches to improve healthy food access and choices among vulnerable communities. The research tested multiple innovations through a discrete choice experiment (DCE), including bulk purchases of fruits and vegetables from local farmers, stokvel-owned vegetable gardens, and short courses on healthy food topics such as urban food gardening, nutrition, food preservation, and budget-friendly meal planning. The project also developed digital engagement tools including a social media community page (Facebook) to facilitate discussions about making healthier food choices on a budget, and created a webpage with practical resources such as recipes for healthy culturally salient meals and tips for storing fresh food. This systemic intervention explored an alternative approach in the South African food system targeting health and nutrition impacts in low-income communities, with findings showing that partnerships with local farmers and community-led agricultural initiatives could motivate stokvels to prioritize healthy food purchasing despite challenges with market power and initial lack of demand for healthy food access.
outcomes.geography: South Africa
outcomes.target_population: Women-led grocery stokvels and their members in low-income urban communities; vulnerable community members; stokvel leaders as potential trainers or advocates; smallholder local farmers. The project also supported 1 thought leader, 1 mid-career researcher, and 2 early career researchers (1 PhD student and 1 post-doctoral fellow).

Results of the DCE suggest that options such as bulk purchases of fruits and vegetables from local farmers and establishing stokvel-owned vegetable gardens are significant motivating factors for stokvels to purchase healthy food. Additionally, short courses focusing on healthy food topics were identified as potentially influential.

This project was seen by the FEH program as an opportunity to explore an alternative and innovative systemic intervention in the South African food system with health and nutrition impacts in low income communities.

outcomes.description: The project strengthened capacity of researchers and practitioners to promote gender equality and inclusion in climate-resilient food systems through multiple mechanisms. The project supported capacity building for 1 thought leader, 1 mid-career researcher, 1 postdoctoral fellow, and 1 PhD student, all focused on women-led stokvels, gender dynamics, and financial inclusivity in food systems. The research team, with strong women representation (the PI and two of three co-investigators were women), developed and applied innovative research approaches and tools including realist evaluation and discrete choice experiments (DCE) designed to understand women's economic agency and decision-making in food systems. These efforts directly addressed women's empowerment among economically marginalized populations and enhanced institutional capacity to integrate gender equality into food system research and policy. The project also engaged with the Western Cape Government Department of Health and Wellness to explore expanding health promotion initiatives to include stokvels, leveraging the social capital of these women-led groups.

outcomes.description: This project produced high-quality, southern-based research and evidence on the potential of women-led grocery stokvels (rotating savings and credit associations) to increase access to healthy food in South Africa. The research outputs included two peer-reviewed publications (a systematic review on informal savings groups and food security, and a stakeholder mapping study), with two additional manuscripts under preparation, as well as a realist evaluation and discrete choice experiments (DCE). Key findings revealed that stokvels serve as crucial platforms for women's economic empowerment and collective decision-making, but face barriers in accessing healthy food due to cost perceptions, lack of leverage against larger food system actors, and limited awareness about nutrition. The research identified motivating factors for healthy food purchasing including partnerships with local farmers, stokvel-owned vegetable gardens, and nutrition education short courses, providing evidence-based recommendations for food system transformation and policy advocacy.

outcomes.target_population: Women-led grocery stokvels and their members, predominantly women from economically marginalized backgrounds in urban areas; researchers including 1 thought leader, 1 mid-career researcher, 2 early career researchers (1 PhD student and 1 post-doctoral fellow); stakeholders including local government health and food systems actors, policymakers, and potential wellness champions

project_name: Enhancing the design of the Adaptation Futures conference for a more distributed participation in the context of limited international mobility

outcomes.description: The Adaptation Futures 2023 conference developed and tested multiple innovations to enhance inclusivity, equity, and sustainability in climate adaptation conferencing. Innovative session formats were piloted, moving away from traditional one-directional presentations to dialogical, co-produced, and embodied forms of interaction, with mentoring support, dedicated physical infrastructure (IT resources, flipcharts, movable tables), and a target ratio limiting traditional panels to 30% of sessions. The project tested a hybrid conference format with Regional Pavilions (Latin American/Caribbean and African pavilions) that enabled distributed participation while reducing carbon emissions, supported by 227 travel grants (100 to Global South participants, 120 to Canadian Indigenous people), connectivity grants, visa support, and adapted abstract review processes. Additional innovations included a mentoring program for early career researchers, dedicated Indigenous engagement protocols with an Indigenous-led partnership organization, and multi-sited dialogue workshops held across three distinct event formats (virtual, multi-hub, and hybrid) to evaluate different conference models through SWOT analysis. These innovations directly addressed systemic barriers faced by historically under-represented groups and resulted in 80-90% acceptance rates for session submissions from Latin America/Caribbean and sub-Saharan Africa compared to 50-60% from North America/Europe.

outcomes.description: This project successfully developed and tested nanobubble technology for multiple innovative applications in aquaculture across Asia, involving smallholder farmers in piloting and testing the technology. The research team evaluated nanobubbles through laboratory experiments and scaled up to small commercial ponds, testing applications including pathogen control during bacterial disease outbreaks in shrimp and finfish, enhancement of vaccine efficacy and antigen uptake for immersion vaccines, water quality improvement, antimicrobial removal from aquatic environments, and microbial community management in earthen ponds. The project produced 17 published scientific papers, 7 industry workshops, 6 scientific presentations, and a practical app (https://nanobubbles.shinyapps.io/nanobubble_flow/) to help farmers calculate equipment costs and requirements. The technology was incorporated into the City University of Hong Kong's veterinary service, offering nanobubblers for free to small aquaculture farmers who wanted to test the innovation, generating significant farmer interest and influencing private sector companies to design nanobubblers specifically adapted for aquaculture use.

outcomes.description: This project produced extensive southern-based research evidence on nanobubble technology applications in aquaculture across multiple scientific disciplines including molecular genetics, pathology, bioinformatics, immunology, vaccinology, and microbiology. outcomes.description: This project developed and tested multiple innovative tools and frameworks for promoting healthier food environments across East Africa. Key innovations include: (1) the first-ever implementation of the Food-EPI (Healthy Food Environment Policy Index) tool in Uganda and Tanzania to assess food environment policy implementation against international best practices; (2) development and adaptation of a legal and political feasibility assessment tool (FELIP) that evaluates the probability of success for implementing child-directed marketing restrictions and simplified nutrition labelling policies, which will be made publicly available for adaptation by other researchers; (3) a Nutrient Profiling Model and Front-of-Pack Nutrition Labelling (FOPNL) system developed in collaboration with WHO and Kenya's Ministry of Health to help consumers make healthier food choices; and (4) methodological innovations in documenting unhealthy food marketing to children and conducting cost-of-illness analyses for diabetes. These tools and frameworks represent systematic innovations being piloted and tested to address food system challenges related to nutrition and non-communicable disease prevention.

outcomes.description: Cocoa cooperatives and smallholder farming families in Côte d'Ivoire were meaningfully involved in developing, co-creating, piloting, and testing multiple climate adaptation innovations throughout the project. A gender-sensitive decision-support tool for climate adaptation was developed through participatory processes involving cooperative boards, staff, committee representatives, and diverse members (ensuring female participation), combining climate scenarios with agroecological practices; this tool was tested, used by cooperatives, and made available for national extension services (ANADER). Agroecological adaptation practices were identified, characterized, and promoted, including agroforestry systems, tree planting for shade and windbreaks, compost production from cocoa residues, and improved solar dryers for cocoa beans, which were adopted by farmers and integrated into extension curricula. User consultation activities were adapted to remote formats (questionnaires and telephone interviews) during COVID-19 to ensure continued participation of cocoa producers in co-creating climate scenarios and interpretation tools. The innovation development process strengthened cooperative capacities in planning, accessing, adopting, and applying climate-responsive solutions while deliberately integrating gender considerations throughout, including in tool design, practice selection (trees chosen based on differentiated needs of women and men), and decision-making processes.

outcomes.target_population: Cocoa cooperatives (3 participating cooperatives) and their member families including smallholder cocoa farmers and producers (both women and men), with deliberate inclusion of women farmers and focus on ensuring meaningful female participation; cooperative boards of directors, staff, and committee representatives; vulnerable cocoa-producing communities; climate experts and researchers
